description.narrative: Conservation Area project aims : Torricelli Mountain Range - Support to Torricelli Mountain Range Conservation Area.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1. Capacity Development Indicator score for East Sepik Province, West Sepik Province and Tenkile Conservation Alliance. 2. Extent of area under different National PA Categories and covered by Integrated Land Use Plans to direct management of proposed Torricelli Mountain Range Conservation Area. 3. Stable or increased populations of threatened species – proposed Torricelli Mountain Range. 4. Formal agreements in place between communities in participating Government/ project IAs, to provide financial and in-kind support to additional resources per household participating communities, resulting in additional resources per household.

comment.narrative: Capacity score: East Sepik at 23%, West Sepik 21% and Tenkile Conservation Alliance 53% METT score: Torricelli 57% Torricelli has 0 ha under formal Protected Area arrangements Tenkile Tree Kangaroo (Dendrolagus scottae) (Critically Endangered) Population estimate 300+ and Weimag Tree Kangaroo (D. pulcherrimus) Population estimate 500+ Additional resource per household at US$ 0 in TRM

1- mapping/zonning of MTR completed with 50 community agreements on proposed TMR conservation area. 2- Each village has conservation area committee 3- TCA, CA communities Rangers and Provincial government officials training on Protected Area Management 4- Aiming to lunch PA June 2018

All five LLG's and Sandaun Provincial Government (West Sepik) have passed resolutions supporting the TMRCA. During this reporting period TCA has made three attempts to obtain a resolution from East Sepik Provincial Government - August 2017, October 2017 and January 2018. This process is on-going with TCA initiating further meetings soon after the up-coming LLG elections (July-August 2018). It is TCA's opinion that due to many administration changes has meant disruption in our communications, networking and relationship building with this Provincial Government.
An official submission of the TMRCA to the Minister for Environment was initiated by the Managing Director of CEPA in late May 2018. Sandaun Provincial Government has endorsed a resolution to provide TCA with financial assistance, ~K25,000pa, for the next five years.
TCA launched its movie Into the Jungle with UNDP in Melbourne on 31st August 2018 for further exposure of the UNDP GEF partnership. Smaller events are planned for rural Australia and PNG throughout the second half of the year as part of our strategy to influence Government to support the establishment of the TMRCA.
TCA has 50 villages, within 5 LLGs, participating in the project area, comprising of ~13,000 people. Benefits include: TCA Rice Farming: To date a total of 14 Rice milling machines have been purchased under this project ten of which have been distributed throughout the project area. One machine has been given for each team A-H (x8) and one in Yangkok LLG and one in East Wape LLG. Each Rice Milling machine has its own management plans to outline the procedures for use for each area. Two of the LLG's (Palai and West Wape LLG) need to supply TCA with their management plans before receiving the machines. The Drikikier LLG needs to show more support for the project. This machine is being held at the TCA base. One machine is at TCA Base and will serve as a training and demonstration model indefinitely. TCA Fish Farming: materials distributed to 47 villages. A few more materials need to be distributed to villages due to some logistical challenges and confusion over material numbers with staff. Fish fingerlings have not been distributed as part of this project. All villages have access to several fish stock sources. TCA has conducted awareness that the fish people receive are not native and fish ponds are to be made 100 meters away from any natural water sources. TCA Rabbit farming: TCA's Rabbit Trainer/Project Officer has received support to strengthen the Rabbit project in Wigote village. This will result in improved husbandry/housing of rabbits. To date: wire for enclosures, 6 x 15m rolls, and a 9000L water tank for the rabbits has been distributed. TCA Cocoa Project: Cocoa nursery under construction at TCA Base -Lumi. Area cleared, flattened & framework for nursery, ~10m x30m, installed. Partnership with the Cocoa and Copra Initiative (CCI) has not resulted in any financial support for materials. A one week course was conducted twice during October 2017 with 60 participants (8 women attended). Participants were from both the project area and neighbouring villages. TCA will be receiving approximately 600 seedlings of a new cocoa variety in the second half of 2018. TCA Vanilla Project: Vanilla, within & around the TMRCA, is the second most popular cash crop after cocoa. Due to community involvement & pursuing our financial sustainability options, TCA undertook a feasibility study of vanilla. From February 2017-February 2018, 12 months, TCA networked efficiently with vanilla exporters, businesses & PNGs Department of Quarantine. In March 2017 TCA obtained an export licence to send vanilla samples to be tested for vanillin percentage and quality. TCA sent staff to Port Moresby on five occasions, conducted three Skype meetings with connections in Madagascar, Belgium & France & had staff collect data on the two species of vanilla presently being grown in the area. TCA executives (CEO and COO) met with a world leading vanilla buyer, Biofirst, in Brussels for a whole day to learn and discuss ways forward for the project. After our 12 month 'Feasibility study' the TCA Board, TCA reps & staffs' decided to not proceed with TCA buying & exporting vanilla - due to the high level of risks & work load involved. The current high market value provided no tangible benefits for TCA to proceed and TCA concluded it will, as it does with cocoa, see its role as building capacity & provide assistance to strengthen the management of local co-operatives in buying & selling of vanilla.

Activity 2.3 : Formal gazettal and effective management of the Torricelli Mountain Range Conservation Area (TMRCA). Targets: 1. Launch gazettal of TMRCA on World Environment Day June 5th 2020. 2. Complete Mapping and Zoning towards the proposed TMRCA Integrated Land Use Plan with accompanying 50 Conservation Area Agreements. 3. Initiate the establishment of a Conservation Area Committee in all 50 villages. 4. Complete varied learning opportunities for TCA, CA Communities, Ranges and Provincial Government Officials training on Protected Area Management
Activity 2.4: Community Livelihood Assistance in the Torricelli Mountain Range landscapes proposed CA: Alternative protein Targets: 1. Facilitate Review of Conservation Area Agreements with 50 villages. 2. Representatives from 50 participating Communities with >K400 ($150 USD) in additional resources (fish/rabbits, rice, solar, housing, cash crops) per household per year. 3. Complete socio - economic study and village profiling for 50 participating villages. 4. 90% Community Development projects implemented.

The Government IP CEPA is responsible for facilitating the gazettal of the proposed TMR CA and due to several formal objections raised by the proposed TMR CA communities, the CEPA consulted with said communities and objectors for most of 2020 and held the last meeting in November and the resolution was that there were no real objections to the gazettal. CEPA is currently compiling their consultation reports to recommend the gazettal of the proposed TMRCA. TCA advised CEPA that the gazettal area will be reduced due to some villages pulling out of the proposed TMRCA area so that the proposed gazettal of the TMRCA will cover an area of 143,000 ha. It is anticipated that the gazettal will be granted in 2021.

1) launch gazattal of TMR PA in Sep 2019 2) complete mapping and zoning towards the integrated land use plan with accompanying 50 conservation area agreement 3) initial establishment of a conservation area committee in all 50 villages 4) complete varied learning opportunity for TCA, CA communities Rangers and provincial government officials training on PA areas management.

With the support of the Project and under the leadership of UNDP, investments made supported communities address climate and disasters risks. Efforts to improve food security were enhanced with support to expand fish farming to supplement protein intake for 47 villages in the Tenkili Conservation Area. This was complimented by a mini-solar programme that rolled-out panels, lights, regulators and inverters to over 150 homes, while another 300 homes receiving tin roofing that will improve shelter and water collection.
